message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of asthma, but spirometry findings are normal. Methacholine challenge testing can help identify underlying asthma by measuring bronchial hyperresponsiveness. Skin-prick testing is used to diagnose allergic reactions, which may not be the cause of the patient's symptoms. Ciliary studies are not appropriate for this presentation. Clinical observation without further evaluation is not appropriate as the patient's symptoms are impacting her quality of life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest exercise-induced asthma, and the best next step is a methacholine challenge test to confirm the diagnosis. Skin-prick testing and ciliary studies are not indicated in this case. Clinical observation without further evaluation is not appropriate as the patient is experiencing significant symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest exercise-induced asthma, but spirometry is within normal parameters. Methacholine challenge test is the best next step in diagnosis as it can help identify any airway hyperresponsiveness that is not detected on spirometry. Skin-prick testing is used to identify the allergens causing allergic symptoms, which is not the main concern in this case. Ciliary studies are used to evaluate ciliary function, but there are no indications of this being an issue in this case. Clinical observation without further evaluation is not recommended as the patient's symptoms are concerning for asthma and further evaluation is necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms strongly suggest asthma, but as spirometry findings are within normal parameters, further testing is required. Methacholine challenge test is used to provoke bronchoconstriction and diagnose asthma in patients with normal spirometry findings. Skin-prick testing is used to diagnose allergies and ciliary studies are not relevant in this case. Clinical observation without further evaluation would not be appropriate as the patient’s symptoms can significantly impact her quality of life and may require treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest asthma and spirometry may not always be conclusive for diagnosis. Methacholine challenge test can induce bronchoconstriction in patients with asthma and therefore, it can aid in diagnosing the condition. Skin-prick testing and ciliary studies are not relevant in this case. Clinical observation without further evaluation is not appropriate as the patient is experiencing significant symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of asthma, which is a clinical diagnosis. Spirometry findings may be normal in some patients, so a methacholine challenge test is needed to establish the diagnosis. Skin-prick testing may be useful in determining the allergen triggers, but it doesn't clarify the diagnosis. Ciliary studies are not indicated in this case. Clinical observation without further evaluation is not appropriate, as treatment is needed to prevent exacerbations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest possible asthma, which can be confirmed by a methacholine challenge test. Skin-prick testing may also be helpful in identifying triggers, but it does not confirm the diagnosis of asthma. Ciliary studies are not relevant to asthma. Observation without further evaluation is not appropriate given the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB) which can be confirmed by a methacholine challenge test. Skin-prick testing is not indicated as the patient does not have significant allergy symptoms. Ciliary studies are not indicated as the patient does not have any suggestive symptoms of ciliary dysfunction. Clinical observation without further evaluation is not appropriate as the patient is experiencing significant symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest asthma, but her spirometry findings are normal. Methacholine challenge test can help diagnose mild asthma that may not be detected on spirometry. Skin-prick testing and ciliary studies are not relevant for asthma diagnosis. Observation without further evaluation is not appropriate, as the patient is experiencing symptoms that affect her quality of life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of dry cough, shortness of breath, and chest tightness suggest asthma, and spirometry is within normal parameters, which could be consistent with exercise-induced asthma. The best next step to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of asthma is a methacholine challenge test. Skin-prick testing and ciliary studies are not indicated for this patient as they do not provide information about asthma. Clinical observation without further evaluation is not recommended as the symptoms could significantly impact the patient's quality of life and could potentially worsen without treatment.
